number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								UPDATE:After the developer's constant patching of the game to improve performance, iron out bugs and adding features, I can now finally recommend Road Redemption. It's far from perfect yet, but it's more than playable, and offers hours of play with a decent variation in the level design, weaponry, challenges and so on. The mere fact that the devs have been working SO hard on improving the game is honestly reason alone to support the team and the game. While most devs hold off on updating their Early Access games for weeks or even months at a time, Road Redemption seems to be getting a near daily treatment of fixes, improvements and additions. If you have a problem with the game, you are pretty much guaranteed to see it fixed in a patch released before you know it.About the actual game; it's not quite identical to Road Rash, it takes its liberties and brings the craziness up to 11, sometimes potentially a little too much for some players. But most people should be able to enjoy what it offers, the spirit of Road Rash is definitely there. And as soon as we can get proper online multiplayer, I'm sure this will be one kickass game with tons of laughs to be had.-----------------------------------------------------------ORIGINAL:Not quite yet!I backed the Kickstarter project and I'm REALLY looking forward to the final product...... But the current build (like every build before it) is virtually unplayable, the performance is simply laughable. Now, there's a lot happening on the screen, but with how ugly the game looks, the performance isn't even remotely justified.I'm sure the game will turn out to be an amazing piece of work at launch (and even during development once the performance is fixed). Hell, I've even had a lot of fun with it the few times when it didn't run at a single frame per second. But right now, you'd be better off saving your money. Because all you'd be doing is pay for a game you can't really play yet. Bugs and the likes, that's what Early Access is all about. Getting players to help out to some extent, during the development. But when it's only marginally playable at all, then it just becomes a little pointless. So keep your eyes on the game, it's bound to be awesome. But it's not quite there yet.

y 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is just plain FUN!  It not only harkens back to Road Rash, but all the arcade games that were easy to get into and gave you that thrill, whether you beat it or it beat you.  You'll notice I haven't played much so far but even if it never gets out of EA, I feel I've gotten my money's worth.  As an aging gamer, my hand-eye is far from what it used to be so I really stink at this game. I can't even get to 3rd place and die more than I survive but I keep going back for more.  To me, that's the mark of a great game.  I've basically moved into walking simulators, point-and-click adventures, and The Long Dark, but I will be re-energizing my heart with this arcade gem in between.

er 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								Yes, it's basically an updated Road Rash and that's awesome.Early Access thoughts:The menus are all really unpolished and give the game a very "Postal 2" feel to it in terms of overall graphics. Still, it's Early Access and the menu graphics are really unimportant to how fun it is to drive around and smash things up.It's pretty easy to run off-road and it's very unrealistic when it happens. Crashing on the road is pretty easy, but crashing into terrain is surprisingly hard. But it's Early Access, so they might fix this.No ability to remap the controls with an XBox controller. It would be nice as I'd rather have X/B be left/right attack rather than X/Y. It's minor and I can adjust, but the default controls still feel unnatural to me.

content:
, 2015
Early Access Review
								Came across this game through the Steam marketplace, but primarily was sold when I watched some Let's Plays on YouTube. Without a doubt a clone of Road Rash and even a bit of Jet Moto mixed in. LOVED playing both titles on the PS1, and have been extremely disappointed EA dropped Road Rash in the past, but now with Road Redemption I can get that same experience back.The combat is much more engaged that it was in Road Rash which is a major plus. I was a bit shaky on the Health system, but with time and weapons at your disposal, falling off your bike and ending your campaign run doesn't seem so common. What really had me impressed was the -mostly- constant spawning of non-racing enemies like cops and random bikers. You really do need more than 15 opponents, you'll find yourself wrecking almost everything on wheels blowing through these rich tracks (which if the loading screen is true, are somehow randomly generated in a very smooth manner).Everything about the game is amazing, from the gameplay to the soundtrack. The long road through the campaign is also rewarded with yet another surprising source of nostalgia as well! Game is full of surprises and I've yet to find myself bored. Would really enjoy some online arcade play or custom race options. An old-school arena mode would be a really nice touch as well to get away from the consistently linear A-B racing style (although racing is primarily the point here).If you're into racers, arcade-style combat, craziness, and player destruction, you need to buy this game. Be it at the current $20 for early access or the expected $30-$40 range of a full release, you will not regret it.

content:
er 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								If one would mixed Road Rash*, Mad Max, Waco, Crazed Punks on Dope, a plethora of guns, knives, axes: modern to medieval... and mixed it with "that shocking high school video of what prom night accidents REALLY look like", then one would have Road Redemption. I have been pleased with the progression of the game, as I have noticed welcome improvements in the graphics and gameplay: both more fluid. The controls seem to be better. either that or I'm getting used to my Xbox game controller. If you are a veteran of the "Original Road Rash" and had a blast with it, well I've had a blast with friends and playing/ watching Road Redemption and hearing the sickening "CRACK" of a sledgehammer hitting some guy's buck teeth and knocking them into powder is a real gasser! This is a game that the devs put a bit of thought into and some surprises made me stare, mouth agape, at the aftermath of a 100mph pile up. I'm loathe to give anything away because I enjoy this game quite a bit and I discover new things that I like every week. I would buy it If I were on the fence, because I did. Wasn't too sure at the start, but recent developments made me a believer and it is, to me, very playable and I love beating down punks who think they are better than me! I'm looking forward to the next update, as I've beaten the game on both campaigns about 10-15 times. Says a lot. I couldn't even make it to level four prior to the dev's welcome updates, although RR has always been enjoyable to me. It really reminds me of Mad Max on LSD! I read it on these forums! Whoever said that, he was right! Crazy, crazy game that had me clenching my teeth and ducking and weaving in my chair, haha! Highly recommended.10/10 Would pump 12 ga buckshot into a biker's rear tire @ 120mph again!*On the Amiga A500w/AdSpeed@14.28MHz 1MB RAM

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Absolutely Cracking. Just finished my 1st play-through and i'm very impressed. Obviously it was a little short but in open access I expect little compromises. It's a very familiar pattern to Road Rash of old with level after level of wild tracks to race. It can be quite seat of the pants type stuff at times with clever dips and rises hiding oncoming traffic, crazy debris spinning about the track, suicidal cop cars etc etc etc. It has a great structure of purchase based add-ons and experience based ones to fine tune your rider for the oncoming challenges but could really use the same to customise and personalise your bike itself. At this time, it could definitely still do with some fine tuning (for example Road Rash's agonisingly long run back to the bike after crashing would add a greater price for recklessness) but all complaints are minimal to the joy you'll get watching a man you've just kicked into oncoming traffic get wiped out by a logging truck. If it was a bigger full game with competitive online multiplayer and the tweaks ironed out it'd be a certain 8 or 9 out of ten. Great work bringing back a sorely missed classic.

Early Access Review
								Just finished the Early Access game, holy cow was I impressed! First, the game looks amazing.  Second of all, I felt like I was 5 years old playing the Classic Road Rash, but this game is balls to the wall fast, 99% faster then what I expected, the missions are somewhat difficult, but don't worry if you fail them... You can still continue but without the cash reward at the end of the race. And also, give that number a call! Ian is a very nice man. Didn't mind me calling him at quarter to four in the morning to dicuss the game! (I called thinking it was just a computer recording)Thoughout my play through of the game I've only had the game crash on me twice, which is not bad, the error reports are sent when you relaunch the game. The Missions are a little repitive but still none the less pretty difficult, and the controlls are SOLID (I perfer using the gamepad, but use the keyboard and mouse if you want to use the guns, and rifles)10/10 would HIGHLY reccommend if you want a casual, hardcore arcade-ish feeling racing game!A few things I would LOVE to see in the final build of the game....Bike customization, Story line, few cutscenes here and there, and more areas to play!

content:
2015
Early Access Review
								Really excellent game so far. Mostly just needs more content: more bikes, more tracks, more music, more opponents, more weapons. Could definitely do with an over-the-top announcer and an option for some blood and bigger explosions. Would love to see a few extra game modes, preferably including a Burnout-like mode for causing maximum mayhem given certain limits--timer, weapons, or the original your-vehicle-is-a-guided-weapon.It's been a while since I played a good, meaty arcade racer where all I had to worry about was moving fast and mashing or blowing up my opponents without the game getting in its own way. This game delivers in spades. I just want to see *more* of it.Controller strongly recommended.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
r 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								In it's current state, v0.813, the game is already an incredible amount of fun.If you like racing and/or melee combat you should really give this a try.Cause for a game that relies on motercycle races and swinging weapons it's a suprising lot of fun.Weapons ranging from sledgehammers to battle axes to C4 give enough variation to wanna try them all.The campaign mode currently exists out a number of missions to complete like a normal race, attract police, kill a number of enemies (sometimes without using weapons). These modes are mixed up with some crazy stuff like cars dropping from the sky, driving on rooftops or even using jumpjets. Gotta say the first time those cars came down I was like 'What up with that? AWESOME!!!' On the other hand it can also be slightly frustrating in the later levels, cause if you die you start from scratch. The game uses two types of 'powerups' one persisted and bought by XP the other only counting a lifetime and are bought with money earned for taking down enemies and winning races. These 'powerups' are mainly about, get more life, get stronger, get more ammo for weapons etc.The races itself are extremly frantic and fast paced, this will cause you to crash from your bike every now and then showing a ragdoll effects which reminds me much of fallout 2. And with all the sillyness in the game already who knows it might get a stunt mode as well? :DThis version does not have the competitive mode yet so i'm really looking forward to that, cause that could make or break a game like this.Now to sum up what I really like about the game- Awesome fast paced racing and combat- Funny diversions like raining cars and jumpjets.- A good set of weapons.- The temporary skills (don't like the permanent ones so much, it makes the game a lot easier).- It's easy to drop in for just a few races.So far i've run into a few issues:- Inifite loading bug, usually occurs around mission 11 for me, havent been able to play that mission yet.- Framerate can be a bit low in certain places (however i don't doubt this will be fixed).- Firing weapons with a gamepad can be a bit tricky, the default rb key to shoot doesn't feel right for me. I also kinda doubt that using a gamepad for competitive mode later on will be a real option since shooting with the mouse is way to accurate to be fair.All in all I can only say I think this game is on it's way to being awesome.For an early access title it's already very playable aside from the loading bug and the framerate issues.Considering it's an early access title I would rate this 8/10.Great job, DarkSeas Games.

Using nitro. At top speed.Using a weapon from a bike going.. 180 MPH? And you're controlling it with one hand...

ber 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is really fun. Very addicting. Ive been playing it for quite a while even before it came to steam and i have seen a lot of improvements to it. Its still quite buggy and a lot of things dont make any sense to me but it sure is a blast. The crashes are kind of amazing. The graphics are nice. The music is sort of so so. Sometimes its elevator music and sometimes its hard rock. It plays sort of like a rouge like game. The missions are somewhat random and you have one life to get to the end of the game. At the end of each level you have some time to buy health and pther upgrades with the money you earned in the previous event. Once you die, you can spend some experience points on permanent upgrades that will help you in your next attempt. I have yet to beat it but im getting pretty far now. Its hard to stop playing once you have started. I cant wait to play this with friends. It really does bring back old road rash memories.I very much recommend this game. Even in its broken state of early access its still a very enjoyable game. Get it on a sale and have a blast.

content:
r 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is still in Early Access, so be aware that it contains several bugs and it is constantly changing until it'll reach it's final form. However, the devs are releasing updates quite frequently (every 2-3 days) and they're taking seriously the customers' responses and actively participating in the forum too.This game is a motorcycle-action game, similar to the old Road Rash games, but in a modern form and improved with several great ideas. The graphics is beautiful and meets all modern requirements a game needs today. The controls are very responsive, and easy to get used to it, however you'll need both your hands, because the action buttons are on the mouse (if you play it with keyboard and mouse of course). There are several "game modes" (inside campaign and campaign+ and competitive is coming too) and those are varying map by map, for example takedowns, attract police, "simple" race, race on rooftops, takedowns without weapons, etc... There are at least a dozen weapon from tire iron, through battle axe, to the AK47 and the devs are promised there will be more. Right now this version of the game contains 4 types of maps, which are desert, snow, rooftops and the Rainbow Road.I have 17 hours in this game when I'm writing this review and I never bored a single second or was frustrated by anything. The 20€ may seems a little bit too much for this Early Access game, but I need to tell you, it is worth the price and it contains more fun than a lot of the AAA++++++, trillion budget, overhyped games.

content:
ber 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								When I first fired up this game I didn't know what to think, it certainly isn't the prettiest game out there and it could use a bit of polish, but give it 10 minutes and you'll be hooked. If any of you have played Road Rash for the N64, Road Redemption is like that but on bath salts and with guns. A few issues I have with the game are when there's a lot of ♥♥♥♥ onscreen like when a logging truck spills logs all over the road or if there's a "car storm" the FPS drops to the single digits. The city rooftop tracks are also pretty shafty especially when you're forced to use the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ grappling hook to swing from crane to helicopter. Bugs aside this game looks really promising and hopefully once coop is added and the campaign mode is fleshed out it will get better.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								Road Redemption is refreshed old Road Rash on Mega Drive and Play Station. It has all what we loved in these games: tons of adrenaline and madness, hi-speed fights and destruction (hoping of some wild life in the future of RR). But there is some new stuff: - firearms (AK47 and M79 Blooper are taste so good!),- races across rooftops (use jump jets and grapple helicopters with a harpoon),- and finally - ride a rainbow!So, if someone hasn't decided yet - remove all doubts and buy!PS And try to imagine yourself ride the bike while shooting with a lever action shotgun (just like in Terminator 2 movie) in truck carrying logs (Final Destination 2) to release them right on your opponents... That's awesome!

ber 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								When I first fired up this game I didn't know what to think, it certainly isn't the prettiest game out there and it could use a bit of polish, but give it 10 minutes and you'll be hooked. If any of you have played Road Rash for the N64, Road Redemption is like that but on bath salts and with guns. A few issues I have with the game are when there's a lot of ♥♥♥♥ onscreen like when a logging truck spills logs all over the road or if there's a "car storm" the FPS drops to the single digits. The city rooftop tracks are also pretty shafty especially when you're forced to use the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ grappling hook to swing from crane to helicopter. Bugs aside this game looks really promising and hopefully once coop is added and the campaign mode is fleshed out it will get better.

Early Access Review
								Road Redemption is refreshed old Road Rash on Mega Drive and Play Station. It has all what we loved in these games: tons of adrenaline and madness, hi-speed fights and destruction (hoping of some wild life in the future of RR). But there is some new stuff: - firearms (AK47 and M79 Blooper are taste so good!),- races across rooftops (use jump jets and grapple helicopters with a harpoon),- and finally - ride a rainbow!So, if someone hasn't decided yet - remove all doubts and buy!PS And try to imagine yourself ride the bike while shooting with a lever action shotgun (just like in Terminator 2 movie) in truck carrying logs (Final Destination 2) to release them right on your opponents... That's awesome!

content:
ber 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								SPIDERBIKE! SPIDERBIKE!  More like SPIDER RASH... I backed this thing up because I'm hopelessly addicted to the 1995 Roadrash for PC (remember the friggin awesome Soundtracks on that one?) the rail rider mechanic (having the screen pull your bike around wherever the road bends and you got to pull in that direction to keep in lane or avoid collisions). Expect me to endlessly compare this UNITY engine stinker to the good ol' boy classic. My name is Milwaukee Jon !Now I know this is Early Access and I am writing TWO notes here to edit this review whenever I see significant changes.First off: Unity? FFFFFUUUUUUUUU...Runs like @$$. I'm serious. I have seen better Tetris 3D clones with more destruction and particle effects that run like a waterfall (constant). I have just recently grabbed Receiver (thx Bundle store) for free and I am willing to accept its low poly plastic look that runs as $H!T as anything else with the touch of the Unitron. I guess the engine was picked for a reason (looking at you Linux and MacOS) but ffs is it underperforming.Could be because I do not own a 1337 PC GAMING MASTER RACE accredited machine. I don't give two about that becaue I played games in the past decade that a) run like hell and b) look like paradise at the same time while you get your lil avatar ♥♥♥ raped by the superb AI that handles most of your surroundings. All the while my machine was switched to energy saving settings.Anyway: Soundtrack is a bit here and there. I really like some of those electro tunes (shiz beatz and all the shebang) but on the other side the metal tunes cannot possibly compare to the grunge awesome that was included in the classic. However if you compare the stage themes (there were 5 in the classic) and this one that puts random themes everytime you reload a stage I guess it is somewhat better because you know it is an actual track and not a MIDI tune with fake instruments from the system repository.Controls: As I expected it is an upgrade in dimensions. You have thrusters to do quick jumps and doubletap to activate a constant booster instead of boost capsules that needed to be timed well in the classic to have an effect. You can turn around, drive here and there, only limited by the camera pitch towards the center but OH WAIT, mouse now controls the camera and the combat. The one hit takedowns work nicely and blocking seems to be OK. There is even a hook gun that when mastered can become your best tool while chasing rivals or evading obstacles. Spiderman approved!Video and Settings: Change resolution, windowed or FS, AA, VS. all that $H!T takes a nose dive because on weak rigs you can pretty much forget about it. Doesn't matter what you pick. Fastest is still beyond min. playability. The more is happening on screen the worse stuttering gets. I usually just skipped the city rooftop stages whenever I lost too much HP cause they are pointless when the best I get are 12 FPS...Gameplay: One hit takedowns (crticals) are often, booster gets me up to max speed when I need it but doesn't help chasing well placed opponents although the game cuts you some slack like the classic did. The opponents are often gathered near frontrunner so if you manage to drive fast and not fly off your bike or get  stuck  SUPER GLUED  to the rear of a car (wtf man?) then you have a good chance to overtake all them suckas at once (thx to the popo beating up everyone and occasional car storms (yes you heard right, CARS dropping out of the sky onto the track like ultra heavy rain drops of the apocalypse!!!). I felt like a D@m/\/ wizard while a few hundred meters in front of me cars spawned out of nowhere and crushed the opposition and pesky pigs. As mentioned in the beginning. Hook gun comes complete with bungee rope and all that gud stuff. While midair you can turn directions like Mario and not give a flying pair of ducks about inertia or silly physics. YOU ARE THE PHYSICS! Oh what is that, a huge boulder? NOPE! it's a perfectly fine ramp. Just dash into it and get catapulted back on track while blasting fools from above with your hitscan AK, UMP, Shotie and grenade launcher. Hell yeah.I guess at this point I gotta pull the emergency brakes: See, the classic was inspired by the console versions. The combat felt up close and personal because you AND your rivals had a health bar that regenerated once downed. It was fists vs. fists, chains, bats. The opponents had names displayed in the corner. They even had UNIQUE outfits and bike colors ffs (d@mn boy (speaking of Early Road Redemption), you gettin yo 4$$ handed to ya by a 20 year old game you tried to surpass). That's right, rival gangs, popo and all that SHARE most of the looks. One surprise I found was that some random racers drove CARS! Wohoo, I can't bash your teeth in but I sure can blow you up with sticky TNT or that nice 40mm launcher.Then again, the basic get up in the classic was a helmet, a two colored bodysuit, and the color of your bike. The popo had fat bikes and leather with an open helmet so you could see their faces when punching them off their bikes. This one surprises me.Nobody wears helmets (only random ♥♥♥♥♥ drivers wear those), everyone is beating everyone of different color, the cars just run into you when you try to slow down, Coppers don't play it save, the cars do incredible amounts of colateral damage, the police is more interested in murdering than in real life minus the use of guns (would be too OP I guess).What I am trying to say here is that basically I like some of the new stuff but laugh at the lack of detail that's been put in the visuals and the behaviour. Everyone is bat$H!T insane and the truck drivers are dropping deadly logs on purpose causing endless waves of crashing cars and taking you off your bike (I guess those things get nerfed sooner or later). It makes the feels go away and make way to a different kind of frustrating. Needs way more polish guys.One example in combat dynamics: Here only the toughest makes it out alive (most of the time it is you because everybody else gets knocked the EFF out from one hit criticals or quick 2 hit combos or simply mowed down by gunfire thank god it isn't autoaiming like in some other bike racing games *cough* Jacked *cough*). Once you manage to crash enough times (mostly thrice) then it is bye bye and you gotta restart your career in a parallel universe as the Game Over screen keeps tellin yo stOopid @$$ (or spend EXP on a "NEW" concept of advancing the plot. Yes, a PERK let's you skip the beginning stages). The perk system is very funny at that it COMPLETELY bypasses SHOP, CLUB HOUSE, SAVE TOILET. Yep. Want a better bike? only 100XP for starters, want higher character stats? moar EXP please. Want to gain more for less? EXP is currency, money is for the YOLO campaign items. The concept of YOLO is exactly that. Where the save feature made devastating bike damage pointless in Rash: oh you failed, bike is gone, money is gone, go back to square one and ... oh wait just load your last save. Redemption goes: PFFUUU...CK saving, better transcend space and time and possess another racer that looks exactly like you and condemn him to the same if not worse bone shattering death! Oh and go back to the beginning lowie.Character traits are gone completely. You are the same a-hole all the time occasionaly your dummy driver comes with a helmet. Watch out we got a badass over here. You can steal weapons from everybody else but why would you when the missions are short and your own stash of multiple murdering tools is more than enough. Oh right. Weapon degradation. No ammo refills, no slice and dice. Every hit takes a chunk out of weapon condition. No more endlessly swinging your bat in the face of oncoming rivals.What I expect in the future: Biker Names - at least the OppositionMoar creativity with the bikes - customizationMUCH longer stages. MUCH LONGER.5/10

content:
er 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								A brutal racing game with a large arsenal of all kinds of weapons at your disposal. Still missing a lot of features like multiplayer, but the singleplayer campaign has a decent amount of variety to keep you hooked. You gain experience as you play, which can be used to unlock new abilities or bonuses. During the games you can also gain cash to use for temporary upgrades that you lose upon death.As it is still in early access, you have to expect a lot of bugs and glitches. Have only seen a game breaking glitch once so far that forced me to restart the game. Smaller ones like being able to fire a gun after you are knocked out, flying in the air, even while not even holding it.Pro:- Great soundtrack (though somewhat repetitive).- Lots of different weapons and tools to choose from.- Decent AI- Responsive & good controlsCon:- Lack of vehicle variety- Still in a glitchy state (expecting it to be a lot better in time)- Lack of online multiplater yet (This game would really benefit from a multiplayer mode soon)

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
er 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								I’m the type of guy that to this day still has my Sega Genesis with Road Rash hooked up to my Television, so when I learned about Road Redemption it was an instant buy for me. When I first started playing, I was a little leery, as it is so clearly early access. The models aren’t the best (especially the collision models); it’s poorly optimized, there are no key re-bindings… but above all, it’s still a blast to play. The level design is great, the combat system is like Road Rash on steroids, the weapon selection is massive ( who doesn’t love taking someone out with a claymore, mace, or harpoon gun?), and the developers actually care about feedback. For a measly $12 I got to spend a night with my best friend barreling through deserts, forests, and rooftops all while beating and shooting our way to victory. The game still has a long way to go before it’s finished, but the concept is solid and the team is obviously dedicated to making a great game. I highly recommend it, even in its current state.

content:
8, 2015
Early Access Review
								Road Redemption is based on a documentary of one man's crusade to protest the over-hunting of the majestic butterfly whales. Disgusted by humanity's rapacious slaughter of those beautiful creatures, he determined that the only way to impact positive change was to stage a sit-in protest in front of the White House. This game covers the cross-continental journey from the dazzling west coast to the seat of corruption.Along the way, the young man makes shocking discoveries. The most unsettling is the realization of his own innate violent desires. Unsure how to reconcile them with his noble mission, he lashes out at many bikers who are pursuing their own goals on the lonely roads. The entire time, he is haunted by a semi -- clearly a metaphor for his unstoppable ambition and the pain and destruction it leaves in its wake. His days are filled with explosions, bludgeoned heads, and ragdoll bodies. Eventually, as he nears DC, he comes to a dramatic revelation: Drugs are bad for you. I mean, seriously, what the hell is a "butterfly whale?" What was he smoking when he came up with that?EDIT: I learned I was in contravention of international law ("All endangered species shall be described as 'majestic'). I profusely apologize and have undergone penance (a 24-hour Discovery Channel marathon).

content:
er 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								What the game is about? kicking and smashing the competitors faces in while riding your bike and avoiding traffic. The game comes with dynamically generated raods, a few variations in mission objectives that all seem to lead towards a boss fight of sorts represented with a red skull.Im an avid fan of older games and road rash, it was one of those games that was amazing to play with friends, sure it took quite alot of effort to find the right keys being on the same keyboard and whatnot, but the fun was worth it. What has been changed compared to the good old game? The game has race and hitman modes, but the most interesting addition by far is the "hallucinogen ride" where they chuck falling cars on the road while you ride, here dodging traffic takes a whole new meaning. The game also introduces a wide variety of weaponry including guns that werent in the predecessor game, althou hard to aim, they can be a big help in several situations (they even have a rocket launcher!) Overall the opposition interaction isnt there yet (if it ever gets implemented since the current bikers are faceless goons who you tend to forget real easy) and the recing part lacks the "racing part" as the game focus is too much on combat. What do i mean? enemies you have left behind easily catch up to you and your forced to retaliate, its too easy to catch up once youv fallen or been smacked off your bike.For now i have tried only the single player mode of this game and am loving it quite alot. Sure the game has a few kinks to work out but its a real masterpeice of early releases. So if kicking and hitting your fellow bikers while doing a race is your kind of fun, then i whole heartedly reccomend this game, but the game is still missing a chunk of the heart that used to be road rash.

content:
er 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								The motorcycle/beat em up arcade game Road Redemption is absolutely amazing eventhough its still has some flaws its well worth the money. The game is in early acces as i write this review but its still works fine but could need a little polish and a bug fix here and there. but when that is said i havent laughed this much when playing a pc game since i played southpark stick of truth and even then i might actually have laughed even more at this one. the game can be played by up to 4 players at the same screen and eventhough i only have played the single player yet, then i can see the endless fun in that. To my understanding an online mode will be implemented at some point where players will be able to create gangs roaming in the game and fighting other online gangs. hopefully in the final version there will be more levels and options to choose them when wanted and hopefully steam cloud will be implemented aswell. besides of that i would personally like when the whole gang implementation/co-op is done that every gang can create a patch for theyr jackets of the gang.  So if you like speedy motorcycle games and sneaking up on strangers and give them a good whack to the head with your baseballbat then this game is deffently a game for you and if you absolutely want a super realistic driving experience then you propably should move on. so all in all this is a great game even in this early access state i'll give it an 8/10  but with a couple of improvements i dont see no reason why it wont be raised in the near future.  So go and support this game as it will improve as more join the game and if not then you can expect a whack to your head one of these days but that also applys if you join this great game :)

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
8, 2015
Early Access Review
								Road Redemption is based on a documentary of one man's crusade to protest the over-hunting of the majestic butterfly whales. Disgusted by humanity's rapacious slaughter of those beautiful creatures, he determined that the only way to impact positive change was to stage a sit-in protest in front of the White House. This game covers the cross-continental journey from the dazzling west coast to the seat of corruption.Along the way, the young man makes shocking discoveries. The most unsettling is the realization of his own innate violent desires. Unsure how to reconcile them with his noble mission, he lashes out at many bikers who are pursuing their own goals on the lonely roads. The entire time, he is haunted by a semi -- clearly a metaphor for his unstoppable ambition and the pain and destruction it leaves in its wake. His days are filled with explosions, bludgeoned heads, and ragdoll bodies. Eventually, as he nears DC, he comes to a dramatic revelation: Drugs are bad for you. I mean, seriously, what the hell is a "butterfly whale?" What was he smoking when he came up with that?EDIT: I learned I was in contravention of international law ("All endangered species shall be described as 'majestic'). I profusely apologize and have undergone penance (a 24-hour Discovery Channel marathon).

content:
17, 2016
Early Access Review
								Was a huge fan of the original road rash and had hopes this would recapture that feeling. When it first released it was unplayable garbage that had no right being up for sale. I should have refunded it then but kept it with hopes for the future. Now it's prettier but still just doesn't feel very smooth, just doesn't capture the adrenaline. -Bike handling and the physics seem very off-the attack animations and hitboxes seem way off and -the 'progress' is so annoying. I fired it up again recently to play a bit and had to ctrl+alt+del it because it just throws you pointlessly into these really simple races with boring objectives one after the other and there is no way to just do a race or two and quit.-the advancement/money system feels very tacked on and pointless. I have no idea what I am actually progressing towards when I win a race or why I should care. For background, I don't usually play racing games but two of my favorite games of all time are Road Rash and Burnout. After so long in early access they can add better graphics but it does not seem like they can capture the fun factor of the original and they don't seem to understand that so I have lost faith this game will ever be the one I had hoped for.

content:
0, 2016
Early Access Review
								If I had to rate it out of 10 - I would rate it a 4. It's a coherent game; it has options and split screen multiplayer. There are bikes that race and you can knock each other off. That's about where the good stuff ends.Every bike feels floaty and weird; as in the physics just feel wrong. I often felt like I was flying or something - and in one level on roof tops that is literally the case. The combat which could have been really simply is needlessly convoluted, with randomized pickups; randomized starting weapons ranged weapons that are either over powered or utilize clunky aiming controls.... I hate the music. Just. Ugh - as someone who probably played a thousand hours of Road Rash on my crappy Sega I wanted to love this one really bad but everything about it feels like a let-down. I can't tell if its the nostalgia that ruined this one for me; or the game itself - but I wouldn't recommend it to anyone. There are better standard racers; and as long as Blur still exists there are better combat racers. It could get better because early access; but I'm not hopeful. I may come back to it in a couple years and see if its any better. Until then I'd give this one a wide berth.

number of helpful: 9 of 19 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
9, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have never cursed at a game as much as I have at this one, but it's also the most fun I've had with a game in quite some time. At times it's frustratingly difficult, but that just makes the times you make it through all the more special. I would name myself a jaded gamer, I struggle to find as much joy with games these days. However this little gem of a game has come along and helped me rediscover a bit of gaming joy.There's a definite feeling of speed, and both the combat and dodging of obstacles can give that on-edge feeling where your breath stops for just a moment as you wait those milliseconds to see if you edged it. There's rightly a lot of comparisons to Road Rash, but this game stands out on its own merit. It has a whackyness that surpasses the prior game, and the feeling of progression is different as well, at least in this early access edition. Road rash felt more gradual, whereas this game throws you right into things. Said progression is a bit strange in Road Redemption, but it has its own charm if you have the patience.The game still needs work, there are some strange occurances and the odd crash, but the patches have been coming thick and fast and I am confident it will only get better. It is already an extremely enjoyable game and I highly recommend it.

content:
, 2015
Early Access Review
								Guess I'd better write a more-accurate review!First-most, after I posted my first review, I got a friend request from "ROADREDEMPTIONDEVELOPER". If you're into that sort of thing, great - but bewarned.The actual review is quite simple;You're a dude with some sort of grievance with the world (but nobody is really quite certain what that is), and you must race motorbikes and kill other people, also riding motorbikes (or sometimes in the form of a truck, or Humvee). I'm not really sure why.You must "take down the bosses", like some rebellious 1980's youth without a reason to do so. You must "Race other gang members to the finish". You must avoid cars flying from the sky, and be sure to smash other (unaffiliated?) riders faces in with a range of weapons I thought unlikely to see again since Postal 2.Why am I not recommending this game? Two reasons - It runs like a donkey pretending to be a goat.annnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnd the story didn't grip me.(The story? yeah....You know the one I've just described above....yeah, that one.)Even the reason/s to keep playing are sparse, there's no real progression to speak of, and I kind of wish there was. You don't really have a story mode, and there's no real explanation to whatever is happening in this turbid, confusing world of drugs and violence.

content:
r 9, 2014
Early Access Review



YouTube™ Video: Road Redemption [Early Access Review] 

			Views: 101		

			My review of the build 0.814 of "Road Redemption" by Dark Seas Interactive, The Fisch Brothers, Pixel Dash Studios, Fish Factory Games.		

VERSION: 0.814Road Redemption is the spiritual successor to Road Rash, and it's developed by a lot of people.In Road Redemption, you play as a biker that's going from the East coast to the West coast in a post apocalyptic America. The game is a procedurally generated racing action game. There are multiple types of missions, including takedowns, cop attraction, race against bikers or race against time...In the game you get a huge arsenal of weapons: baseball bats, pipes, swords, machine guns, grenade launchers, axes...The driving is really arcady and the attack buttons have to be pressed moments before hitting the opponents, similarly to the whip in Castlevania. The AI works really well, and gets more and more challenging as you go on. In the four areas of the game (desert, rooftops, snowy mountain and a bonus one), there are multiple hazards (like traffic and buildings) or variables (like car rain).Another great aspect of the game is the soundtrack: it is really energetic and fits the game like a glove.There are, however, some problems related to the performance: in some tracks, especially the first one, the framerate drops at 6fps. The developer have assured that they are working on fixing these issues.Overall, this is one of the most action packed racing games I've ever played, it gets constantly updated by the developers and it will feature additional content such as competitive gameplay, character customization and more weapons. One of the best Early Access games to support.SCORE: 90/100

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
13, 2015
Early Access Review
								Road redemption is a game available on steam for Early access and while the game is not fully complete, I feel it is the closest thing you will get to a more modern Road Rash game.EA has a track record of killing off their companies like Westwood and Maxis.So as far as hopes of a decent Road Rash being put on any other platform besides the Genesis or Windows 98 is probably a lost hope.Thankfully Road Redemption seems to be one of the better attempts.While the game is a more pricey indie title, if you are interested in Motorcycle combat games, this is right down your alley.The game is developed by several individuals -Developer: Dark Seas Interactive , The Fisch Brothers , Pixel Dash Studios , Fish Factory GamesEarly access means this game is going to offer consistant updates until a finished product, but currently at this time the game supports achievements, controllers, and new game + modes which allow the continual playing of the game.Fun at it’s core, Road Redmption hardly can be considered a hard core story driven game.The game features a few different charecters including a Shovel Knight skin, but that is all they are just skins.The difficulty determines the speed of the game and damage values, but I found the default to be just fine.Playing through the beginning of the game is pretty simple, albeit a bit more difficult depending on the level, later on  the difficulty does crank up though.The player can invest in upgrades while going through the game, but only while playing, once it’s game over all the money used for perment upgrades and XP is lost.There are also standard upgrades for level to level use like extra life’s, damage, or healing damage.Weapons are a bigger part of this game than the actual bikes honestly, though most of them are identicle from the pipe to the sword, they really almost feel the same.Guns are available in the game and take a huge learning curve to learn, aiming and shooting is difficult to say the least, but the most effective way of dealing with enemies.Cops and other drivers make an appearance as well, and attempt to chance the player down at any given chance.Random crashes do occur frequently and can throw you off your game often, making it difficult to just race and have fun.Overall though, the game is fun and grants multiple levels to play through as of now.I am also told multiplayer will be coming soon as well.I would recommend this game to anyone familiar with Road Rash or racing games in general, but not to anyone who is un interested in violent games.I hope you guys enjoyed this review, and I am signing out.Good Gaming and God Bless!

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
22, 2015
Early Access Review
								I was not exactly expecting much when offered to beta test a game by someone with the same name as the game.  After idling for cards one day, I forgot about the game entirely for a month or two.Then I felt guilty and decided to fire it up, figuring I would quit after 30 seconds and move on.I did not expect to get sucked in immediately.  Particularly as I have not liked a racing game since the early 1990s.This game is a great balance of absurdist action fun and enjoyable racing; even trying to do something as simple as watching for cars barrelling straight at you while you also try to maneuver into the perfect position to club a nearby racer to death proves excellently challenging.But what really seals the deal of this being a game worth playing is the reward system--receiving cash at the end of every race that you can use for temporary upgrades, and then experience upon death (based on your successes in the races) that can be used for permanent upgrades, is a pretty addictive system.  It certainly kept me playing longer than I expected, and I found myself planning out my next upgrades without even realizing it.So, overall, a racing game worth playing for people who hate racing games--probably even for people who love racing games!

content:
y 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								As a big fan of the Road Rash series (Road Rash 3 in particular), I really really want to like this game. My friend and I played this on splitscreen for about two and a half hours, but we never felt invested like in the old games. Nothing we did felt particularly meaningful, starting with the character select screen where we had to pick identical characters and bikes. The way the races end is incredibly jarring. As soon as one player crosses the finish line, the level just ends. The second player cannot finish the race, there's no fan-fare, no overview of the race, and no trash-talking bikers. Also, none of the levels feel very distinct from one another. No kangaroos jumping out at you or hitch hikers to run over. Just a generic weaving three-lane highway that seems to loop back on itself ad nauseum (on account of proceedural generated levels, the geography of this game is kinda messed up). The upgrade system feels meaningless as well. You can choose from a number of boxes with static bonuses, as opposed to RR3 where it was all about saving up for that sweet new bike, then decking out the tires and suspension. Jumps also don't do much. In RR3 you'd go off a jump and fly off the f-ing screen. In this there's barely any air or any other real reason to hit a jump. The weapon degradation system is similarly meaningless. You come across weapons so frequently and carry around such a large inventory that you'll never go wanting. In the old games, stealing a pair of nunchucks felt like a huge accomplishment. The police don't do much in this. They won't run you off the road and bust you. They're more there for lip service I guess. I also don't understand why there are so many armed motorcyclists, but only some of them are in the race. I suppose one of my biggest beefs is that the campaign never makes you feel like you're accomplishing anything. In RR3, getting through Japan on level 5 while riding a super bike was a huge feat.I know the game isn't finished, but I can't really recommend it in its current incarnation. I hope it touches up on some of the areas I've discussed. The combat system is fairly satisfying. Grabbing other riders and driving off cliffs is hilarious. I like the detours. Fighting semi trucks is ♥♥♥♥ed lol. I'd probably be way less critical if I wasn't a huge RR3 fan. Despite my numerous criticisms, I seriously admire what they're trying to do here.

content:
r 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								Upon making this review I've only played (about) 3 hours. The Road Redemption team asked if I'd like a free copy to play to provide feedback so here's what I think so far.Again, like I said, I've only played about 3 hours and I've already had loads of fun. Road Redemption is a high octane arcade racing combat survival game (definitely a mouthful). There's no story or voice acting but the gameplay is all you need. Race across rooftops, take out rivals, taunt the cops and try your best to stay alive. That may sound simple but it's challenging. The AI isn't dumb. They've kicked me off of bridges and have blocked my attacks quite a lot. Cars ram into you and trucks drop lumber and destroy anything in their path. The devs made the braking system really soft so you can't easily dodge grenades or attacks being launched at you. Some missions will have raining cars and random ones that will drive completely horizontal to the highway making it even more challenging and random.Of course this game being in early access there are still kinks to work out. I've gotten stuck on terrain and sometimes the hit boxes can be a little off. At times I'll find that respawning on the track I can't move and am forced to quit and their secret racing map seems to end in the middle with no finish so I haven't been able to complete the campaign yet. Online mutliplayer hasn't been released yet but if you have a friend you can play local co-op.  To provide some ideas I would definitely add some voice acting and police sirens. It would also be really cool to have a story along with the campaign to make it more immersive and since it's already crazy...why not add a mission where you have to outrun a ridiculously giant truck along with having to deal with your usual rivals? I'm sure you guys must have lots of ideas and I can't wait to see them in action. Overall, I would definitely recommend this game and I can't wait for more content.

content:
er 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is the type of game that makes me question steam's binary review system - you either give thumbs up or thumbs down, neither of which conveys my feelings about this game. Then again, it's still an improvement from steam's old system, which didn't even have a "no" option at all!So, on to Road Redemption. This game is a spiritual successor to EA's Road Rash series of games, so the main game play consists of beating the crap out of your fellow bikers and trying to be the first to the finish line. But this isn't just a re-skin of road rash with modern graphics. Combat is effectively required, as some missions flat out require you to eliminate enough enemies to advance. But all the missions (save the pure time trials) require plenty of fighting. Taking down another racer will knock them out of the race, and taking down almost anyone will restore some health and nitro, as well as reward some money and their weapon.It's no surprise then, that the developers took care to make the fighting the single best part of the game. There's a lot of depth to the combat, from kicks and grabs to baseball bats and pistols. Kicks and grabs are good for steering someone into an oncoming car or forcing them off a cliff. Melee weapons vary in speed, strength, and durability - for instance, shovels are strong but slow, while bats are weaker but faster. Swords break easily but are both fast and strong. Then you have the guns, ranging from pistols to Uzis and grenade launchers. They are great for shooting other bikers from a distance. Finally, you can deflect an attack from an enemy - if done right it blocks the attack and makes your next attack very powerful. There are various missions and various conditions to preform them under. Most of these are fun, such as eliminataing a certain number of enemies, or attracting police attention. However, the 'time trial' missions lack the fun factor present in the other mission types. They are the only missions with no one to fight, and it seems that there's no reason for these missions to be here, other than "a racing game needs time trials"! Many also cannot stand the 'car rain' missions, where cars literally rain down from the sky and crash into the ground. They'd be pretty fun if it wasn't for the pure randomness of it - it's possible for a car to land right in your way (or otherwise bounce or slide in your wary) with no chance to react, causing an instant crash and a loss of some health. Losing health is a big deal, because unlike in the road rash games where zero health meant losing a few positions, in Road Redemption it's an instant game over! This is the most drastic departure from the classics, where the only way to lose was inability to pay for your wrecked bike or a ticket form the cops. Death means starting back from square one, except for the skills you purchase with XP, which you get to retain between playthroughs. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, as the skills are fairly neat. But it may tick of long-time rashers who just wanted to relive the classics.The game's actual problem lies in it's lack of content. I was able to complete everything this game has to offer within 3.1 hours, according to steam. At present, the campaign is comprised of 12 levels with randomly generated missions, and there is a harder campaign+ which is the same, just harder. There is no story to speak of, and the only multiplayer is local split-screen co-op. This is what made the game so hard to recommenced - 3.1 hours does not justify the game's $19.99 price tag - even if it were 75% off, that's well over a dollar an hour! So why then, is there blue, rather than red, at the top of this review?My final recommendation arises not from what this game currently is, but from what it can be in the future. This game's Greenlight page gives a description of a story featuring multiple outcomes depending on your actions, as well as facing betrayal from your gang, and leading your own gang at some point later in the plot. This story mode alone would be worth the price if added to the already outstanding gameplay,  but the developer seems to be active in the forums and seems to express a desire to add plenty of other content, and already has added quite a bit since early access release. Based on what this game can become, I ultimately must recommend this game. I must make sure to revisit this review in the future once the game is completed, whenever that may be.UPDATE: Road Redemption has undergone an engine change. Historically, an engine change mid development results in classic games like Daikatana and Duke Nukem Forever. Thankfully, this game may be an exception to the rule.The boring time trial missions appear to have been removed entirely while the car rain missions (referred in-game as "Hallucinogenic chemical zone") have been altered so that cars are always avoidable. In addition, one new track was actually added to the gameGraphics were mildly improved with the engine change. I've been informed that performance has improved though I cannot confirm as my current PC is far over recommended specs. They've been able to add in more traffic and more racers as well - a welcome addition. Jump Jets now have a meter of their own, and only appear on the rooftop missions. The only downside to this change (or perhaps I simply missed this flaw before) is that unaligned traffic seems to target the player despite being supposedly unaligned.

content:
1, 2015
Early Access Review
								Amazing pick up and play arcade-style PC game, and I'd been looking for one of this genre that I liked since I got Steam a year ago... this is the one. It has all the feelings of classic Road Rash (this is coming from a Sega Genesis veteran who by the way was decently disturbed by the violence in the game when I was 4)... ...and this violence is understandably much worse in this modern day game (not in a bad way)... it has a decent amount of blood and a sort of disturbing sound effect when the melee weapon cracks against the body of an opponent. Yes it's disturbing, but it kind of puts a moral urgency on whether or not you want to violently and bloodily slam someone off of their bike and probably maim them for life. But I don't want to make it seem like the violence is overwhelming. It's just enough to be funny and in your face but not overdone.Immediately fun, easy controls, and it has an interesting old school game path where you progress through levels and if you die you have to start over. Kind of gives you more of an initiative to keep playing, I feel.Sure I've only played a half hour so I can't know for sure about replayability or longevity, but I'm sure when online multiplayer is released it will be a huge plus, not to mention local split screen co-op which I've also been scarcely pleased with on Steam for a year. Great game!

content:
ry 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								The controls are a bit sloppy, the graphics are a bit fuzzy, and the physics are certainly not spot on, but damn it, I have fun playing it. Good ol' fashioned video game fun right here folks. I absolutely loved the original Road Rash series, and this makes me smile just like it did. Motorcycles, cattle prods, and grenade launchers...what's not to love?The developers continue to improve the gameplay, and those sloppy controls/graphics/physics I mentioned are being improved upon as the weeks pass. I just did a playthrough on 7/20/15, and the graphics/controls are definitely better than when I first played the game in February. Everything appears much sharper than before, and it feels a bit more like actually riding a motorcycle. The physics have been made more realistic as well, although there are a few hiccups at times when I'm pretty sure I pass straight through objects. More than anything, I just hope multiplayer gets added (I'd love to have co-op, cracking skulls on motorcycles with a friend? Yes, please).At this point, it's worth at least a solid 15-20 hours of single player gameplay. Is that worth $20 bucks? For me, yes. If multiplayer ever gets added, I'd absolutely recommend buying it without hesitation.

content:
ber 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								I expected the speed and the violence. On the store page, Road Redemption looks like a sort of Mario Kart meets Sons of Anarchy mash-up. What I was not prepared for was the extra depth of the rogue-like packaging it would come in. A single crash won't take you out of the race, but if your lifebar is drained, either by too many wipeouts or by other bikers, that's it. That campaign run is over and any winnings are left behind. Experience, however, which is accumulated over the course of the run, can only be used at its conclusion. That experience is used to purchase permanent perks which make your future bikers stronger and net you more money and/or more experience in future runs. After those perks are purchased, the experience total from that run is wiped away and you start from scratch, plus those permanent perks of course. The speed, the violence, and the adrenaline all make for an entertaining experience on their own, but past that, what really stuck me about Road Redemption is that I only started winning races once I noticed that the other cars on the road actually follow normal traffic patterns - as much as one can with motorcycles flying around every which-a-way of course. That means that the most obstacle-free places to travel, and thus the fastest, are the medians. You can jockey around cars as long as you understand that oncoming traffic needs to be avoided differently than the traffic you're following, but you'll only be able to relax and build speed safely once you've returned to a median. It's a surprisingly realistic situation for a game that revolves around swinging an ax or firing a grenade launcher from a speeding motorcycle.

I don't believe I've ever played a racing game with a free-floating camera before, and I don't see how it adds anything to the experience. It mostly serves to confuse the player because the vehicle rarely lines up with the view properly, and when I do move the camera in a driving game, I expect the vehicle to steer towards the camera.It might be a better experience later on, but for now it's the most frustrating experience I've picked up from the recent Steam sale.

content:
ber 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								I expected the speed and the violence. On the store page, Road Redemption looks like a sort of Mario Kart meets Sons of Anarchy mash-up. What I was not prepared for was the extra depth of the rogue-like packaging it would come in. A single crash won't take you out of the race, but if your lifebar is drained, either by too many wipeouts or by other bikers, that's it. That campaign run is over and any winnings are left behind. Experience, however, which is accumulated over the course of the run, can only be used at its conclusion. That experience is used to purchase permanent perks which make your future bikers stronger and net you more money and/or more experience in future runs. After those perks are purchased, the experience total from that run is wiped away and you start from scratch, plus those permanent perks of course. The speed, the violence, and the adrenaline all make for an entertaining experience on their own, but past that, what really stuck me about Road Redemption is that I only started winning races once I noticed that the other cars on the road actually follow normal traffic patterns - as much as one can with motorcycles flying around every which-a-way of course. That means that the most obstacle-free places to travel, and thus the fastest, are the medians. You can jockey around cars as long as you understand that oncoming traffic needs to be avoided differently than the traffic you're following, but you'll only be able to relax and build speed safely once you've returned to a median. It's a surprisingly realistic situation for a game that revolves around swinging an ax or firing a grenade launcher from a speeding motorcycle.

content:
ber 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								More satisfying then Sniper EliteDid you ever play Road Rash? Did you like it? If so then this game is for you. Buy it immediately.This game takes Road Rash, a motorcycle racing game with violence, gives it more modern graphics, and then kicks it up a few notches. It's got all the basics. Bludgeoning your enemies, kicking them into oncoming traffic, grabbing them and forcing them into obstacles, shooting them, etc. All your normal, violent, motorcycle race needs. But that's just the beginning.A few levels in you might experience cars dropping from the sky. Why? Hell if I know. But man does it cause a lot of destruction. On level 4 your bike gets Jump Jets. Congratulations, you can now jump several dozen feet in the air. Sound crazy? It's not. Mostly it's just useful. It's also fun as hell. Beginning on Level 5 you start racing across skyscraper rooftops, and yes, it's as fun as it sounds. More fun in fact because you get a grappling hook that allows you to swing your way to victory. The only downside is that it's a bit hard to use. But when you do use it, man do you soar through the air.And it just keeps going. The current last level is fantastic. I shall refrain from spoiling it and just say that it is a racing game classic and everyone will get a kick out of it. Or hate it. But in a loving, nostailgic way. Future updates will provide more levels I assume.As far as mechanics go, it's decently solid. There's an upgrade system, and a shop. You only keep your money and shop items until you die, but upgrades are permenant. Most controls aren't explained super well, but a quick look at the pause menu will give you all you need.I decided to leave the things I didn't like for last, mostly because some if not all of them are likely to change.-I'm not sure how keyboard/mouse controls are, so I would look into that if you don't have a controller. -The game lags severely on my lower end machine. Going off of looks alone it shouldn't be lagging so bad. Either there's a LOT of computing going on or it's just unoptimized. Hopefully that gets better.-Cars are too strong on early levels where you have weaker weapons. They force you off the road and while you can melee or shoot them, it takes a decent amount depending on the car. Especially police cars.-Aiming mode camera needs to have an option to snapback to defaultAll in all it's a good damn game. You should check it out.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
r 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Before the review begins, i would like to note to everyone that i was given a copy of the game for free from the dev team to review, but this isnt a good review based on a contract. 'Road Redemption' dev team gave me, Angry Video Game Nerd, PewDiePie, Angry Joe and many many others early access to their game for free on the basis that they hope we give them a good review, BUT they did it in a much better way, you arent contracted to say good things, and they have given the game free to big game reviewers simply asking for their opinion. No strings attached, they need honest feedback. I have not been paid anything.Thats the sign of a good listening dev team instead of ya know, the generic corrupt corperation. Doing it this way means that both the people are happy to recieve a free game and test it for them, and the dev team are happy to recieve the reviews and attention the game needs, that's PRO advertising right there. Contracts to give good reviews risks harming your company label when people reveal your corruption *cough EA cough﻿* So firstly i would like to say Thank You devs for allowing me to check out your game! This review is totally unbiast and simply my OWN opinion :)--Basic Review--As you may have already gotten from the Steam Videos, this game involves you riding around on a motorcycle in an infinitely generating world, where the track can take you anywhere from rooftops to the dusty deserts. Map generation is absolutely gorgeous as twisty hills and traps are generated all over the place, including hazardous traffic. Immidiately i was having flashbacks to an awesome game back on the Amiga and other consoles of my childhood, because as you, on your bike meet up with opponent racers with a 'Catch-Up' speed system, and knock them off their bikes with swinging a lead pipe to their faces...my childhood heart started pumping again as it felt like Road Rash was finally coming back to me, the game i had always wanted to be re-made.The game is VERY familiar to Road Rash players, but it goes so much further than that, with the ability to ride an upgraded bike that can jump into the air with booster jets, and swing from helicopters with a hookshot. Even the Cars can sometimes be your greatest opponents in this game as they too, compete against you in many campaign missions.Weaponry involves many melee weapons of different ranges and different strengths all the way to UZi submachine guns and grenade launchers, but here-in comes one of the greatest issues of the game at least as a PC user, KeyBoard and Mouse controls are VERY difficult to master as they become extremely twisty and you havent enough ability to drive, aim, attack, handbrake and all the rest at the same time. It is hard to play (but manageable) with a keyboard and mouse, but ultimately this is a game for a Controller. I Highly advise you grab a dual-analog controller and plug it in to maximize your control here. WASD is not very good at how sensitive you should steer your bike and you are going to need to drive with all of your skills here as the difficulty is quite high.You will certainly get a blast out of this game, especially when the multiplayer module comes out, as PvP in this game is set to be one of the most fun things you have done in many years, all about the skill and not about the diceroll. The game is definitely worth your cash, but also a little patience as it is early access and of course, there are bugs and several things needed to be worked out.--In Depth Review--Graphics: 7/10As you can imagine, worlds which are generated tend to look like they have been generated, rather than natural looking, but that's what makes the race tracks all the more fun than realistic, but the graphics in general are great with lovely lighting and shadows, incredible carcrash physics, lots of particles and bits of things flying everywhere, its great. There are however some major issues which lose the game some points here. There is always this kind of Dust Particle which approaches your screen at almost all times, which actually heats up the computer and in some cases, kills framerate even on powerful rigs like the one im running. Another issue is that large car crashes or great moments of vehicle damage causes the game's framerate to take a divebomb down to like 2 frames per second, which often forces you to kill the game and lose your progress. It's still early access so it's very easy to understand that this sorta thing will happen :)Sound: 10/10Countless games fall victim to a lack of sountrack, a lack of variation, and a lack of adrenaline and emotion to boot, but this game features a large playlist of music, each which will pump up your heart rate and convince you to keep driving and keep smacking people off their bike, the wonderful track lineup really keeps you playing the game so you can listen to them all. I hope in the future, like all games that have featured a kickass playlist (MAX Power Racing, Wipeout 2097 etc etc), will allow you to change track in the Pause menu, because i want to play my favorites over and over again! Maybe they could add buttons to utilize 'Next Track' and 'Previous Track' compatability. Weapons feel so realistic whenever you're in combat, from the sound of slapping meat to teeth-grinding chings of an iron weapon meeting someones skull, it sounds terrifyingly good. I have absolutely nothing to suggest when it comes to their sound lineup.Gameplay: 6/10It feels immidiately familiar to Road Rash players and brings back some well needed nostalgia, adding to what is an adrenaline filled game where every gut wrenching moment you fear for traffic over a hill knocking you off your bike, to battling a horde of cop cars and bikes, to avoiding the bullets and melee tools of an opponent biker and for the love of god keep your eyes on the road else you wont last long :D even the race track is twisty, bendy, requires sharp turns, and wants to kill you. It's very difficult doing all of this at once, but that's the beauty of this game and ones like it in the past, it NEEDS to be difficult and challenging...well it certainly is, sometimes feeling even unfair andd cruelly hard when actually sometimes there is nothing to do when you have been overwhelmed but try to stay alive. My only issue is that Police Cars are far too aggressive, where if a single police car hassles you from the beginning of a race, it is too easy and fast for that car to absolutely obliterate you and you dont always have a gun or powerful weapon to deal with it, making your entire race like trying to push or outrun Superman. As i have already mentioned, this game is hard, VERY hard, which is where i would like to suggest a Difficulty option, so that not-so-skilled players, or casuals can drive on easier tracks, with less aggressive AI and perhaps play a more casual and fun game.There is a lack of Online multiplayer and game-modes right now, but give it some time as there already are plans to include them. It is very likely in the future, the 6 rating i have given, will turn into an 8 or 9 after it has been more developed on :)Overall: 7/10   (after development you could even see up to 9/10)You can tell the game is still early access with several bugs, cars suddenly driving on the incorrect lanes, particle and physical framerate slowdowns and ruthless Car AI, but after these are fixed and more game-modes are included, i would hope with a difficulty slider so people can play at their own pace and level, this game is definitely on it's way to being an instant classic, relivving old memories of games long forgotten but better. The development team are very generous, are listening to community feedback, and are hopefully working hard on this title, because Road Redemption if it continues on this path, is going to be a rolling success. It's just missing one thing, YOU.

The only problem i had with the controls was the aiming with a gun, it seems very hard while controlling your bike and looking out for other cars. For $19.99 though? Uhm.. I'm not sure, it's quite expensive for an Arcade game. However, within the game itself i had no visual problems or bugs it ran solidly on my 5 year old computer.  So all i can say is, if you have the money get it. It's fun and you wont regret, however because of the price, if you're looking for a game around the $19.99 range i'd say hold off until it gets some more features. 8/10, solid gameplay and controls but for the price it may be too expensive for the average gamer.

content:
ber 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								More satisfying then Sniper EliteDid you ever play Road Rash? Did you like it? If so then this game is for you. Buy it immediately.This game takes Road Rash, a motorcycle racing game with violence, gives it more modern graphics, and then kicks it up a few notches. It's got all the basics. Bludgeoning your enemies, kicking them into oncoming traffic, grabbing them and forcing them into obstacles, shooting them, etc. All your normal, violent, motorcycle race needs. But that's just the beginning.A few levels in you might experience cars dropping from the sky. Why? Hell if I know. But man does it cause a lot of destruction. On level 4 your bike gets Jump Jets. Congratulations, you can now jump several dozen feet in the air. Sound crazy? It's not. Mostly it's just useful. It's also fun as hell. Beginning on Level 5 you start racing across skyscraper rooftops, and yes, it's as fun as it sounds. More fun in fact because you get a grappling hook that allows you to swing your way to victory. The only downside is that it's a bit hard to use. But when you do use it, man do you soar through the air.And it just keeps going. The current last level is fantastic. I shall refrain from spoiling it and just say that it is a racing game classic and everyone will get a kick out of it. Or hate it. But in a loving, nostailgic way. Future updates will provide more levels I assume.As far as mechanics go, it's decently solid. There's an upgrade system, and a shop. You only keep your money and shop items until you die, but upgrades are permenant. Most controls aren't explained super well, but a quick look at the pause menu will give you all you need.I decided to leave the things I didn't like for last, mostly because some if not all of them are likely to change.-I'm not sure how keyboard/mouse controls are, so I would look into that if you don't have a controller. -The game lags severely on my lower end machine. Going off of looks alone it shouldn't be lagging so bad. Either there's a LOT of computing going on or it's just unoptimized. Hopefully that gets better.-Cars are too strong on early levels where you have weaker weapons. They force you off the road and while you can melee or shoot them, it takes a decent amount depending on the car. Especially police cars.-Aiming mode camera needs to have an option to snapback to defaultAll in all it's a good damn game. You should check it out.
